449 DISCUSSION 451 In order to solve the problem of indiscriminate use of agricultural pesticides 453 researchers from all over the world are looking for new options for the con trol of 454 pathogens that are efficient, economical and of low environmental impact
A promising 455 alternative is the use of plant defense inducers, alone or in combination with beneficial 456 microorganisms or pesticides [22]

Plant defense bioestimulators , elicitors or activators 457 generally induce a wide range of systemic resistance [23], with a significant reduction in 458 disease symptoms caused by different types of pathogens [24]
The use of mechanisms 459 designed to activate an induced or constitutive defense respo nse in order to prevent 460 plant colonization by phytopathogens is a strategy that has been followed [25]
Elicitor 461 molecules are capable of inducing a defense response in plants, improving immunity 462 and decreasing thei r susceptibility to diseases caused by phytopathogens [26]
These 463 molecules can be extracted directly from microorganisms or synthesized in laboratory 464 [27]
In 2003, Narasimhan and collaborators demonstrated that the increase in the 465 expression of glycoproteins of the cell wall of F
oxysporum f
sp
nicotianae 466 corresponded to a greater severity in the lesions presented in tobacco leaves [28]
Years 467 before, Koga et al
[29] isolated and identified compounds with the elicitor action from 468 the fungus Magnaporthe grisea, a phytopathogen of rice
These compounds had their 469 structures analy zed and were identified as sphingolipids
Treatment of rice leaves with 470 these cerebrosides was able to induce the production and accumulation of phytoalexins, 471 cell death and increased resistance against compatible pathogens
472 In this work, we propose the us e of glucosylceramides (GlcCer) extracted from 473 the mycelium of F
oxysporum as an elicitor of plant immunity as an alternative method 474 to combat diseases affecting the plants
Three molecular species of GlcCer were 475 identified by mass spectrometry in F

oxys porum with m/z 760, 776 and 790, containing 476 the long chain base, 9 -methyl -4,8-sphingadienine, linked by amide bond to 2 - 477 hydroxyoctadecanoic acid (C18: OH), 2 -hydroxyoctadecenoic acid (C18: 1OH) and 2 - 478 hydroxyeicosanoic acid (C20: OH), respectively
These s tructures are similar to those 479 found in other fungi [30, 31] , such as A
fumigatus , C
albicans and Scedosporium 480 species, evidencing the conserved characteristic of this molecule in the different fungi 481 studied

Long chain base (9 -methyl -4,8-sphingadienine) and hydroxylated fatty acids 482 are present in all of these fungi and the difference between these molecules occurs in 483 relation to the unsaturation and size of the fatty acid chain [30]

Several studies have 484 demonstrated the importance of this molecule in crucial processes for fungal cells, such 485 as cell differentiation, growth and viability [30], what may explain why these 486 glycosphingolip ids are highly conserved among different species
487 Umemura et al
[6] purified cerebroside C from various strains of Fusarium 488 oxysporum
This molecule corresponds to N -2'-hydroxyhexadecenoic -1-β-D- 489 glucopyranosyl -9-methyl -4,8-sphingadienine described in our work

Here, however, we 490 characterize also two more cerebroside, N-2'-hydroxyhexadecanoic -1-β-D- 491 glucopyranosyl -9-methyl -4 4,8 -sphingadienine and N -2'-hydroxyeicosanoyl -1-β-D- 492 glucopyranosyl -9-methyl -4,8-sphingadienine
A 2-hydroxyeicosanoic acid (C20: OH) 493 fatty acid is described for the first time in Fusarium oxysporum GlcCer isolated in the 494 present work
495 Analyzing the impact of the F
ox ysporum cerebroside GlcCer treatment in 496 tobacco plants , we assessed its effect on the production of phenolic compounds
Ou r 497 results indicated that GlcCer can induce the production of phenolic compounds in 498 tobacco plants in a time-dependent manner
Polyphenols are secondary metabolites 499 synthesized along the phenylpropanoid pathway
Polyphenols are found abundantly in a 500 wide va riety of foods, such as fruits, vegetables, seeds and cereals, and in beverages, 501 such as wine
They are currently a topic of great scientific attention due to the interest in 502 their potential health benefits
In addition, the class of flavonoids and isoflav onoids can 503 also act as phytoalexins due to their antifungal and antibacterial effect [32]

504 According to Heller and Tudzynski [33], reactive oxygen species play a 505 fundamental role in the interactions between pathogens and plants and it is one of the 506 first events that occur in the recognition of a pathogen by the plant

Besides its direct 507 antimicrobial effect, ROS generation is also involved in cell signaling associated with 508 the expression of genes related to pathogenesis (PR), hy persensitivity response (HR) 509 and also to the development of SAR [33, 34]
In 2010, Kim and collaborators reported 510 that A
thaliana plants that overexpressed the RCI3 gene, which encodes peroxidase, 511 had an increase i n the production of ROS in the roots when these plants had a low 512 potassium availability [35]
In addition, Choi and collaborators also demonstrated that 513 the overexpression of A
thaliana CapO2 gene, which encodes a n extracellular 514 peroxidase in pepper , increased H 2O2 concentrations in response t o infection by the 515 bacterium Pseudomonas syringae [36]
To investigate GlcCer ability to induce ROS 516 synthesis, we evaluated the generation of superoxide radical and hydrogen peroxide and 517 peroxidase gene expression in tobacco plants
Treatment with F
oxysporum GlcCer was 518 able to ind uce the production of O 2- and H 2O2 as detected by histochemical assays
The 519 largest accumulation occurred after 6 h and coincides with the peak of POX expression, 520 as shown by RT -qPCR
521 Umemura et al

[6] demonstrated that treatment of lettuce, tomato, melon and 522 sweet potato plants with a fungal cerebroside was able to induce the production of ROS 523 and the expression of PR genes protecting these plants against F
oxysporum infection
524 In addition, Wang et al
[37] demons trated that the PeBA1 protein extracted from 525 Bacillus amyloliquefaciens was able to protect N
tabacum plants against TMV 526 infection, demonstrating the activity of a molecule of bacterial origin against a viral 527 disease
The results observed here show for th e first time that a fungal GlcCer can act as 528 possible antiviral agent in plants
GlcCer treatment of N
tabacum cv Xanthi plants 529 induced a minimum of 42
8% reduction in the number of necrotic lesions when 530 compared to the control
A 75% reduction was detect ed in younger leaves, indicating 531 the anti -viral potential of GlcCer
532 Elicitation of defense in plants generally is associated to the induction of SAR
533 Among the genes commonly in duced during SAR establishment , increased PR1 534 expression is recognized as one of the main markers of SAR [28, 38]
The silencing of 535 PR1 in Arabidopsis thaliana led to a greater susceptibility to Phytophthora parasitic 536 oomycete infection while N
tabacum plants that shown PR1 gene overexpress ion 537 showed an increased resistance against Phytophthora parasitic and Peronospora 538 tabacina [39, 40]
Here, i t was possible to observe that the PR1 gene expression is 539 highly induced over various times tested , thus indicating the activation of SAR

The two 540 genes encoding for enzymes with antifungal action such as PR3 (chitinase) and PR2 (β- 541 (1,3) glucanase) , presented a similar expression profile, with increased expression 542 between 6 and 24 h

543 As previously mentioned, the establishment of SAR is mediated by the 544 accumulation of salicylic acid (SA) in tissues distal to the site of infection, a nd this 545 accumulation is responsible for triggering the defense response pathway
In tobacco, the 546 main pathway of salicylic acid synthesis is through the phenylpropanoid pathway, 547 which is mediated by the action of the PAL enzyme [41]
The increased expression of 548 this gene is associated with the rapid accumulation of SA [27]
Our results showed that 549 PAL activity increased rapidly in the treated plants
PAL is an enzy me that catalyzes the 550 first step in the metabolism of phenylpropanoids
PAL activity reached its first peak in 551 the first six hours, followed by a gradual increase with 24 and 96 hours after eli citation

552 All plant defense related genes studied in this work showed a strong increase in 553 their expression in the period of up to 6 h after GlcCer treatment , with exception of the 554 gene encoding peroxidase ( POX ), which had a significant increase earlier , after 3 h
555 These data suggest not only the establishment of SAR but also indicate the rapid 556 development of this response
557 The high expression of almost all genes tested, was detected following a period 558 of basal expression or even repression
We hypothesize that these findings could be 559 correlated with the circadian cyc le

NPR1 protein plays an essential role in the 560 transcription of genes related to the circadian cycle and is also involved in the 561 development of plant defense responses and the establishment of SAR [42, 43]
These 562 dynamics between the expression of defense genes and the relationship with the 563 circadian cycle may be related to the results reported above
564 Our results are in agreement with those described by Naveen et al
[7], where the 565 defense mechanisms of pepper plants ( Capsicum annum ) are induced after treatment 566 with a cerebroside extracted from Colletotrichum capsici , a pepper phytopathogen
Th is 567 molecule was able to induce the initial accumulation of H 2O2 and increased the 568 production of the enzymes PAL, POX and LOX
In addition, it was able to protect the 569 plant against infection by C
capsici
Studies by Umemura et al
[44] also demonstrated 570 that cerebrosides extracted from Magnaporthe grisea are involved in th e production of 571 phytoalexins and PR proteins in rice leaves
In field experiments, the cerebroside 572 elicitors effectively protected rice plants against the rice blast fungus, an economically 573 devastating agent of disease of rice in Japan
The cerebrosides also protected rice plants 574 from other disease s
These compounds occur in a wide range of different 575 phytopathogens and act as general elicitors in a wide variety of rice -pathogen 576 interactions [44]
577 According to the results described in this work, it is possible to suggest that F
578 oxysporum glucosylceramide is a strong inducer of systemic acquired resistance which 579 consequent ly induces a high antiviral status in the treated plants
The protective effect 580 observed after treatment is quite expressive and indicates that this treatment could 581 induces tolerance for other plant infectious virus
New experiments must be performed 582 to test this hypothesis
